contentList.content: The strong embrace the wild that hides inside - keen instincts, primal physicality, and most of all, an unbridled, unquenchable rage.

Jump up, down, and across. Your Strength affects how far you can jump.
Costs 2 actions unless you have Quick Jump.
You have -5 to your second attack roll this turn. If your weapon is light, reduce this to -4.
You slash your hand through the air, channeling miniature ripples of air from each finger to slice your enemy.
Project a puff of noxious gas.

2 Actions
Range 30 feet or Melee
Targets 1 creature
Defense AC
You snap your fingers and point at a target, which begins to smolder. Make a spell attack roll against the target's AC, dealing 2d4 fire damage on a hit. If the target is within your melee reach, you can choose to make a melee spell attack with the flame instead of a ranged spell attack, which increases all the spell's damage dice to d6s.
Critical Success The target takes double damage and 1d4 persistent fire damage.
Success The target takes full damage.
Heightened (+1) The initial damage increases by 1d4 and the persistent fire damage on a critical hit increases by 1d4.
Hurl the conjured flame in your hand at a target and let it sizzle out.
Throwing the flame this turn doesn't cost an action. Throwing it on subsequent turns will cost an action.

2 Actions
Range 60 feet
Targets 1 creature
Defense basic Fortitude
An orb of biting cold coalesces around your target, freezing its body. The target takes 2d4 cold damage with a basic Fortitude save. On a critical failure, the target also gains weakness 1 to bludgeoning until the start of your next turn.
Heightened (+1) The damage increases by 1d4 and the weakness on a critical failure increases by 1.
Throw a bubble of acid that damages each creature it hits.

2 Actions
Range touch
Targets 1 creature
Defense AC
You temporarily morph your limb into a clawed appendage. Make a melee spell attack roll against your target's AC. If you hit, you deal your choice of 2d6 slashing damage or 2d6 piercing damage, plus 2 persistent bleed damage. On a critical success, you deal double damage and double bleed damage.
Heightened (+1) The damage increases by 1d6 and the persistent bleed damage increases by 1.
You call upon the Void to harm life force
An arc of lightning leaps from one target to another.
You call down a tendril of lightning that cracks with thunder
Enemies are off-guard to your attacks.
Cannot take reactions and has one less action.
Creature is off-guard. Range of attacks and spells reduced to [1]. Must attempt a DC 11 flat check to target a creature.
Violence is both a means and an end. You follow a path of untrammelled fury, slick with blood, as you thrill in the chaos of battle, heedless of your own well-being.
Your attunement with nature and its beasts inspires your rage, empowering you with supernatural might.
Bards know music is more than idle fancy - it is power. Through study and adventure, these travelling troubadours master song, speech, and the magic within.
You pursue beauty and truth, collecting knowledge from scholarly tomes to peasants' tales, and use your gifts to hold both audiences and enemies spellbound.
You wander the land to witness and relate the deeds of the mighty, keeping alive the memory of heroes of the past and inspiring heroes of the future.

Deities work their will upon the world in infinite ways, and you serve as one of their most stalwart mortal servants. Blessed with divine magic, you live the ideals of your faith, adorn yourself with the symbols of your church, and train diligently to wield your deityâ€™s favored weapon. Your spells might protect and heal your allies, or they might punish foes and enemies of your faith, as your deity wills. Yours is a life of devotion, spreading the teachings of your faith through both word and deed.
Tasked with the holy edict of preserving the body, mind, and soul, your god grants you a plethora of healing magics.
Gods of primordial flame bathe you in resplendent light, providing magics to dispel darkness and immolate enemies.
You wield the unorthodox divine tools of deceit and illusion in worship of your chosen deity.
Druids channel the elemental forces of nature and share a deep kinship with animals. Mastery of Wild Shape allows them to transform into beasts from all over the Realms.

You revere the bounty of nature, acting as both a gardener and warden for the wilderness. With your leshy familiar at your side, you help areas regrow after disasters and turn flora against those who would abuse them.
The uncontrollable call of the natural world courses through your body. Now, primal magic grants you the ability to wear the form of an untamed creature.
Fighters have mastered the art of combat, wielding weapons with unmatched skill and wearing armour like a second skin.
As a paragon of tactical superiority, you employ a wide array of combat manoeuvres to dominate every fight.
You are a warrior of spell and sword, weaving incantations that supplement your extensive martial expertise.
Some reach enlightenment by languid meditation - others do so in the heat of battle. Monks manipulate ki to empower their own strikes and debilitate their foes.
A promise made so deeply that it becomes divine in itself flows through a paladin, burning bright enough to inspire allies and smite foes.
You fight on the side of light in the cosmic struggle against darkness to preserve the sanctity of life and the beauty of nature.
Following the ideal of the knight in shining armour, you act with honour and virtue to protect the weak and pursue the greater good.
You always take what pleases you, no matter who it hurts, and you spread a malign influence across all you touch.
Rangers are unrivalled scouts and trackers, honing a deep connection with nature in order to hunt their favoured prey.
You foster an intelligent bond with a powerful beast that can aid you in and out of combat.
You seek the most dangerous prey in FaerÃ»n, from ancient dragons to massive hordes of undead, and excel at slaying them all.
With stealth, skill, and uncanny reflexes, rogues' versatility lets them get the upper hand in almost any situation.
Your quick hands and mastery of the larcenous arts make stealing second nature - be it from a third floor window or a forgotten ruin.
As quick with a spell as you are with a lockpick, your illusions and enchantments keep opponents on the back foot.
Sorcerers are natural spellcasters, drawing on inherent magic from a gift or bloodline.
Your veins carry draconic magic, the result of a powerful dragon ancestor.
Your powers come from ancient forces of chaos. They churn within you - waiting to burst free at any time.
Bound by a pact to an all-powerful patron, witches trade their loyalty for supernatural abilities and unique magic.
You have pledged your soul to the Hells or Abyss in return for a deadly arsenal of fiendish arcana.
You pledged something unthinkable to an unspeakably ancient entity - which in return furnished you with powers of cerebral entropy and control.
Wizards master the arcane by specialising in individual schools of magic, combining ancient spells with modern research.
You twist and harden the Weave into arcane wards to protect yourself and others. Learning Abjuration spells from scrolls only costs you 25g per spell level, not 50.
You are known as an evoker - striding unharmed through the unfettered chaos you call. Learning Evocation spells from scrolls only costs you 25g per spell level, not 50.
Deal extra damage to a foe you that is in melee range of an ally.
Also works if you have an ally within [1] of the target and you don't have <LSTag Tooltip="Disadvantage">Disadvantage</LSTag>.
Deal extra damage to a foe you have <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> against.
You can also use this attack if you have an ally within [1] of the target and you don't have <LSTag Tooltip="Disadvantage">Disadvantage</LSTag>.

2 Actions
Range 120 feet
Targets 1 creature
Defense Reflex
An ephemeral, taloned hand grips the target, burning it with magical acid. The target takes 2d8 acid damage plus 1d6 persistent acid damage depending on its Reflex save. A creature taking persistent damage from this spell takes a â€“10-foot status penalty to its Speeds.
Success The creature takes half damage and no persistent damage. It is moved 5 feet in the direction you choose.
Failure The creature takes full damage and persistent damage. It is moved 10 feet in the direction you choose.
Critical Failure The creature takes double damage and full persistent damage. It is moved 20 feet in the direction you choose.
Heightened (+2) The initial damage increases by 2d8, and the persistent acid damage increases by 1d6.

2 Actions
Range 120 feet
Targets 1 creature
Defense Reflex
An ephemeral, taloned hand grips the target, burning it with magical acid. The target takes 2d8 acid damage plus 1d6 persistent acid damage depending on its Reflex save. A creature taking persistent damage from this spell takes a â€“10-foot status penalty to its Speeds.
Success The creature takes half damage and no persistent damage. It is moved 5 feet in the direction you choose.
Failure The creature takes full damage and persistent damage. It is moved 10 feet in the direction you choose.
Critical Failure The creature takes double damage and full persistent damage. It is moved 20 feet in the direction you choose.
Heightened (+2) The initial damage increases by 2d8, and the persistent acid damage increases by 1d6.
Hurl a sphere that deals [1] and possibly creates a surface on impact. Alternatively, choose a different type of damage.
Hurl caustic energy that damages the target and creates an <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="ACID">Acid</LSTag> surface on impact.
Hurl freezing energy that damages the target and creates a frosty surface to knock creatures <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PRONE">Prone</LSTag>.
Hurl fiery energy that damages the target and creates a <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BURNING">Burning</LSTag> surface on impact.
Hurl lightning energy that damages the target and creates an electrified surface on impact.
Hurl poisonous energy that damages the target and creates a bubbling surface to <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="POISONED">Poison</LSTag> creatures.
Hurl a sphere of thunderous energy.
The next <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Roll</LSTag> against this target has <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag>.
The next <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Roll</LSTag> against this target has <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag>.

Range 60 feet
Targets 1 creature
Defense AC
You call forth a powerful blast of pressurized water that bludgeons the target and knocks it back. Make a ranged spell attack roll.
Critical Success The target takes 6d6 bludgeoning damage and is knocked back 10 feet.
Success The target takes 3d6 bludgeoning damage and is knocked back 5 feet.
Heightened (+1) The bludgeoning damage increases by 2d6.

Range 60 feet
Targets 1 creature
Defense AC
You call forth a powerful blast of pressurized water that bludgeons the target and knocks it back. Make a ranged spell attack roll.
Critical Success The target takes 6d6 bludgeoning damage and is knocked back 10 feet.
Success The target takes 3d6 bludgeoning damage and is knocked back 5 feet.
Heightened (+1) The bludgeoning damage increases by 2d6.

Range 60 feet
Targets 1 creature
Defense AC
You call forth a powerful blast of pressurized water that bludgeons the target and knocks it back. Make a ranged spell attack roll.
Critical Success The target takes 6d6 bludgeoning damage and is knocked back 10 feet.
Success The target takes 3d6 bludgeoning damage and is knocked back 5 feet.
Heightened (+1) The bludgeoning damage increases by 2d6.

Range 60 feet
Targets 1 creature
Defense AC
You call forth a powerful blast of pressurized water that bludgeons the target and knocks it back. Make a ranged spell attack roll.
Critical Success The target takes 6d6 bludgeoning damage and is knocked back 10 feet.
Success The target takes 3d6 bludgeoning damage and is knocked back 5 feet.
Heightened (+1) The bludgeoning damage increases by 2d6.
Weaken a foe: they deal half damage with weapon attacks using <LSTag Tooltip="Strength">Strength</LSTag>.
Shoot a bright flame from your fingers that explodes upon contact, torching everything in the vicinity.
The glyphs explode and hurt everyone within range when stepped on by an enemy.
The glyphs emit a gust of wind that pushes everyone back when stepped on by an enemy.
The glyphs emit a soothing magic that puts everyone within range to <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="SLEEP">Sleep</LSTag> when stepped on by an enemy.
Hurl a flask of liquid fire that explodes on impact.
Hurl an acid vial that explodes on impact.
Aim two attacks at a target.
Shoot [2] magical darts, each dealing [1]. They always hit their target.
Shoot [2] magical darts, each dealing [1]. They always hit their target.
Shoot [2] magical darts, each dealing [1]. They always hit their target.
Move up to your speed of <LSTag Tooltip="MovementSpeed">Movement speed</LSTag>.
Creature has one extra action each turn.
Muster up your stamina to heal yourself.
Can only be used once per Rage.
Conjure a flaming scimitar in your hand that deals [1] and sheds bright light in a [2] radius and dim light in a [3] radius.
The blade can be unequipped and equipped again, but has to stay on the spellcaster's person.
Heal yourself and all nearby allies for [1]. Regain another [1] next turn.
Protective shadows surround you. They increase your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmourClass">Armour Class</LSTag> by 3.
Create 3 illusory duplicates of yourself that distract attackers. Each duplicate increases your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmourClass">Armour Class</LSTag> by 3.
Whenever you successfully evade an attack, one of the duplicates disappears.
Whenever you successfully evade an attack, one of the duplicates disappears.
Deal [1] extra damage with melee and improvised weapons and thrown weapons.

Gain <LSTag Tooltip="Resistant">Resistance</LSTag> to physical damage, and <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on Strength <LSTag Tooltip="AbilityCheck">Checks</LSTag> and <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag>.

Your <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="RAGE">Rage</LSTag> turns into a frenzy! You gain <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_FrenziedStrike">Frenzied Strike</LSTag> and <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Throw_FrenziedThrow">Enraged Throw</LSTag>. You can also make an <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Throw_ImprovisedWeaponBerserker">Improvised Weapon Attack</LSTag> as a bonus action.
Enter a <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="RAGE">Rage</LSTag> that makes you tough enough to stand up to any punishment.
You can use <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_FerociousAppetite">Unrelenting Ferocity</LSTag>, and have Resistance to all damage except Psychic damage.
A protective shell envelops you. It reflects any projectiles targeted at you back to their point of origin.
Draw on your stamina to heal yourself.
Your staff or club becomes magical: it deals [1], and uses your <LSTag Tooltip="SpellcastingAbilityModifier">Spellcasting Ability</LSTag> for <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag>.
Call forth spirits to protect you. Nearby enemies take [1] or [2] per turn, and their <LSTag Tooltip="MovementSpeed">movement speed</LSTag> is halved.
Magically assume the shape of a beast.

While in animal shape, you can't talk or cast spells. You take on the attributes of your beast form - excluding your Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores.

When your beast form drops to 0 hit points, you revert to your normal form.
Heal your allies and increase their hit point maximum by [1].
Heal your allies and increase their hit point maximum by [1].

Your allies will regain the maximum <LSTag Tooltip="HitPoints">hit points</LSTag> possible when healed. They also gain <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on Wisdom <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> and Death Saving Throws.
Channel fey magic to <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="CHARMED">Charm</LSTag> nearby beasts and plants.
Let your darkest emotions burst forth as a menacing pulse to <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="FRIGHTENED">Frighten</LSTag> nearby enemies.
You and nearby allies gain <LSTag Tooltip="Immune">Immunity</LSTag> to Falling damage.
You and nearby allies gain <LSTag Tooltip="Immune">Immunity</LSTag> to Falling damage.
You and nearby allies gain <LSTag Tooltip="Immune">Immunity</LSTag> to Falling damage.
Heal all allies you can see.
Draw on the Plane of Fire to melt the ground and create a small lava surface under you.
Dismiss yourself from your summoner's service.
Grow in size to become stronger.

You gain <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on <LSTag Tooltip="AbilityCheck">Ability Checks</LSTag> and <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> using Strength, and weapon attacks deal an additional 1d4 damage.
Let the rage build within you. Once it overflows, you'll be able to attack multiple times per turn.
Filled with a furious anger, the gnoll can attack multiple times on its turn.
Increase your <LSTag Tooltip="Strength">Strength</LSTag> by 3, at the cost of decreasing your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmourClass">Armour Class</LSTag> by 1.
Bolster nearby allies with a supernatural resolve. Their attacks deal an additional [1].

Bolster nearby allies with <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="HOBGOBLIN_LEADERSHIP">Leadership</LSTag> and mark nearby non-believers as the <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="HOBGOBLIN_LEADERSHIP_ENEMY">Absolute's Enemy</LSTag>.
Go into a frenzy, increasing your size and becoming stronger through raw anger.

While raging, your melee attacks deal an additional [1].

You gain Resistance to physical damage, and Advantage on Strength Checks and Saving Throws.

You can use Frenzied Strike.
Gain <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag>. Attackers also gain Advantage on Attack Rolls against you.
Emanate a static discharge that buffs nearby constructs and hurts all others.
Nearby constructs deal an additional [2] to weapon attacks. All others take [1] per turn and can't take reactions.
Stomp the ground to cause a massive shockwave and knock nearby creatures <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PRONE">Prone</LSTag>.
Take the shape of a wolf.
Take the shape of a white wolf.
You and all allies in the area gain a +1 status bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls.
Bless allies within 15 feet. They gain a +1 bonus to <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag>.
Gains a +1 bonus to <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag>.
Each flammable target is hit with [1].
<LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="COLOR_SPRAY">Blind</LSTag> creatures up to a combined [1].

Targets drop everything and become <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="FEARED">Fearful</LSTag>: they have <LSTag Tooltip="Disadvantage">Disadvantage</LSTag> on <LSTag Tooltip="AbilityCheck">Ability Checks</LSTag> and <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag>.
If the target ends their turn where they can't see you, they can make another <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throw</LSTag> to shake off their fear.
Summon a strong wind that clears all clouds and pushes creatures back [1], forcing them <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="OFF_BALANCED">Off Balance</LSTag>.
Release a wave of thunderous force that pushes away all creatures and objects.
Affected entity has -2 to Attack Rolls, AC, and Saving Throws.

<LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLINDED">Blind</LSTag> a creature. <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag> against it have <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> and the foe attacks with <LSTag Tooltip="Disadvantage">Disadvantage</LSTag>.

<LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="CHARMED">Charm</LSTag> a humanoid to prevent it from attacking you. You gain <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on Charisma <LSTag Tooltip="AbilityCheck">Checks</LSTag> in dialogue.
Enemies have Advantage on <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> against being Charmed.
You and your allies are revitalised as though you would have taken a <LSTag Tooltip="ShortRest">Short Rest</LSTag>.
You and all allies in the area gain a +1 status bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls
You inspire yourself and your allies with words or tunes of encouragement. You and all allies in the area gain a +1 status bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls.
You've improved your combat skill. Increase your <LSTag Tooltip="ProficiencyBonus">proficiency rank</LSTag> for weapons and unarmed attacks by [1].
You fully understand your weapons. Increase your <LSTag Tooltip="ProficiencyBonus">proficiency rank</LSTag> for weapons and unarmed attacks by [1].
You've developed a knack for dodging danger. Increase your <LSTag Tooltip="ProficiencyBonus">proficiency rank</LSTag> for Dexterity <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> by [1].
Your physique has grown hardy in your adventures. Increase your <LSTag Tooltip="ProficiencyBonus">proficiency rank</LSTag> for Constitution <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> by [1].
Your mental defenses grow stronger. Increase your <LSTag Tooltip="ProficiencyBonus">proficiency rank</LSTag> for Wisdom <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> by [1].

You've learned to move quickly to avoid explosions, dragons' breath, and worse. Increase your <LSTag Tooltip="ProficiencyBonus">proficiency rank</LSTag> for Dexterity <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> by [1].
Your physique is incredibly hardy. Increase your <LSTag Tooltip="ProficiencyBonus">proficiency rank</LSTag> for Constitution <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> by [1].
You are the master of your own will. Increase your <LSTag Tooltip="ProficiencyBonus">proficiency rank</LSTag> for Wisdom <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throws</LSTag> by [1].
Character creation ability scores can't be changed, so this gives a +2 bonus to all ability scores.
Your reflexes are as effective as any armour. While not wearing armour, you add +2 to your <LSTag Tooltip="ArmourClass">Armour Class</LSTag>.
Throw a shard of ice that deals [1]. It explodes and deals [2] to anyone nearby. It leaves an ice surface.
This spell can be cast while you are <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="SILENCED">Silenced</LSTag>.

2 Actions
Range 500 feet
Targets 1 creature
Strike an enemy with lightning. Three more bolts will leap from the target, electrifying as many as twenty other enemies within [1].
Hurl a sphere that deals [1] and possibly creates a surface on impact.

2 Actions
Shoot a thin green ray from your finger. If the [1] reduces the target to 0 hit points, it disintegrates into a crumbly ash.
Launch a ball of churning ice that explodes and damages all creatures and objects within range.
Launch a ball of churning ice that explodes and damages all creatures and objects within range.
Throw a shard of ice that deals [1]. It explodes and deals [2] to anyone nearby. It leaves an ice surface.
This spell can be cast while you are <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="SILENCED">Silenced</LSTag>.

Throw a shard of ice that deals [1]. It explodes and deals [2] to anyone nearby. It leaves an ice surface.
This spell can be cast while you are <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="SILENCED">Silenced</LSTag>.
Call forth the cold mountain winds and reduce the target's <LSTag Tooltip="MovementSpeed">movement speed</LSTag> by [1].
Expel the needles from your body towards a creature.
Leap at a target to bite it and knock it <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PRONE">Prone</LSTag>.
Ice-cold flames shed light in a [2] radius. You take only <LSTag Tooltip="Resistant">half the damage</LSTag> of all Fire damage, and deal [1] to anyone who hits you with a melee attack.
Scorching flames shed light in a [2] radius. You take only <LSTag Tooltip="Resistant">half the damage</LSTag> of all Cold damage, and deal [1] to anyone who hits you with a melee attack.
Become able to see <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="INVISIBLE">Invisible</LSTag> creatures, and possibly reveal them to others.
You raise a magical shield of force. This counts as using the Raise a Shield action, giving you a +1 circumstance bonus to AC until the start of your next turn, but it doesn't require a hand to use.
Expend a Level 4 <LSTag Tooltip="SpellSlot">spell slot</LSTag> to heal yourself.
Expend a Level 5 <LSTag Tooltip="SpellSlot">spell slot</LSTag> to heal yourself.
Expend a Level 6 <LSTag Tooltip="SpellSlot">spell slot</LSTag> to heal yourself.
Take the shape of an air myrmidon.

Your air myrmidon shape has a starting health of [1] that increases every two druid levels. It can cast <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_Invisibility">Invisibility</LSTag>, <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_LightningStrike_Myrmidon_Air">Electrified Flail</LSTag>, and <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_RagingVortex_Myrmidon_Air">Raging Vortex</LSTag>.
Take the shape of an earth myrmidon.

Your earth myrmidon shape has a starting health of [1] that increases every two druid levels. It can cast <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_MetalCoating_Myrmidon_Earth">Muck to Metal</LSTag>, <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_MudSlap_Myrmidon_Earth">Sludgy Sling</LSTag>, and <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_Burrow_Myrmidon_Earth">Burrow</LSTag>.
Take the shape of a fire myrmidon.

Your fire myrmidon shape has a starting health of [1] that increases every two druid levels. It can cast <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_FieryStrike_Myrmidon_Fire">Scorching Strike</LSTag>, <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_BurningRage_Myrmidon_Fire">Myrmidon's Immolation</LSTag>, and <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Zone_RangedSwipe_Myrmidon_Fire">Cinderous Swipe</LSTag>.
Take the shape of a water myrmidon.

Your water myrmidon shape has a starting health of [1] that increases every two druid levels. It can cast <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_FreezingStrike_Myrmidon_Water">Hiemal Strike</LSTag>, <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_HealingMist_Myrmidon_Water">Healing Vapours</LSTag>, and <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Projectile_ExplosiveIcicle_Myrmidon_Water">Explosive Icicle</LSTag>.
Create a shockwave of either divine or malevolent thunder that damages nearby creatures and possibly knocks them <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PRONE">Prone</LSTag>.
Emit a shockwave of malevolent thunder that damages nearby creatures and possibly knocks them <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PRONE">Prone</LSTag>.
Emit a shockwave of divine thunder that damages nearby creatures and possibly knocks them <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PRONE">Prone</LSTag>.

You and everyone around can't be poisoned, diseased, or frightened. Your <LSTag Tooltip="HitPoints">HP</LSTag> increases, and you make Wisdom <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saves</LSTag> with <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag>.
End your <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BULWARK_MODE">Defensive Protocol: Bulwark</LSTag> and return to your normal combat calibration.
Expel a wave of force to push assailants back [1] and knock them <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="PRONE">Prone</LSTag>.
Emit the stench of tomb mould and abattoirs to <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="STINKING_CLOUD">Nauseate</LSTag> nearby foes.
Nausea can be cleared if targets become <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="WET">Wet</LSTag>.
Brand nearby creatures with a sinister mark so that their deaths make you harder to kill.

When a creature frightened by the roar begins its turn adjacent to you, it canâ€™t reduce its frightened value below 1 on that turn. Your first attack that hits a frightened creature after you roar and before the end of your next turn gains a +4 circumstance bonus to damage. You immediately escape from every magical effect that has you immobilized or grabbed unless the effect is of a higher rank than your unimpeded stride spell. You then Stride. During this movement, you ignore difficult terrain and any circumstance or status penalties to your Speed.
Your healing spells restore an additional 2 HP per rank of this spell.

Either you gain temporary Hit Points equal to the spell's rank that last until the start of your next turn, or a target takes 1 void damage per spell rank (if the spell already deals initial void damage, combine this with the spell's initial damage before determining weaknesses and resistances).

Because of the magical power inherent in your blood, your spells that hurt or cure are stronger than those of other spellcasters. When you Cast a Spell from your spell slots that either deals damage or restores Hit Points, you gain a status bonus to that spell's damage or healing equal to the spell's rank. This applies only to the initial damage or healing the spell deals when cast. An individual creature takes this damage or benefits from this healing only once per spell, even if the spell would damage or heal that creature multiple times.

Runes and wards, numbers and lettersâ€”they underpin all magic, making them the logical subject for a wizard who studies fundamental forces. Perhaps you studied at the Pathfinder Society's School of Spells or a similar institution, but whether you're lacing your words with magic to compel others, casting wards around your workshop, or destabilizing the very structure of an opponent's spells, you know this unassuming school carries elegant power.

Magic is power, and there are always those who will use power for the art of battle. You may have studied in the military of a nation of the brink of warâ€”Cheliax and Andoran perhaps, or Geb and Nex. You summon whirling energies that can lay waste to both soldiers and armies, while being sure not to neglect arcane countermeasures for common tactical complications or the shields and defenses that keep combatants alive on the battlefield.

Whether you studied in Manaket's Occularium or the Academy of Applied Magic, you learned that the fruits of arcane studiesâ€”like any other fieldâ€”should ultimately help the common citizen. You've learned the humble art of construction, of finding lost people and things, of moving speedily among buildings and moatsâ€”yet these same arts can be turned to demolition, and the constructs you animate to build bridges can just as easily tear them down.

As a scholar, you know all too well the importance of a sound mind. Thus, you attended a schoolâ€”like the Farseer Tower or the Stone of the Seersâ€”that taught the arts of befuddling lesser minds with figments and illusions or implanted sensations and memories.

The uninitiated often think of wizards as cerebral, focused on their studies more than the body, yet your school of magic taught of the relationship between the two. Your magic, whether learned at a storied institution like Kintargo's Alabaster Academy or someplace more sinister, like the Fleshforges of Nex, focuses on the ways that living matter can be convinced into another shape for a time, allowing you to polymorph a seed into a vine, a human into a beast, or a harmless germ into a deadly toxin.

Why use your magic to affect something as pedestrian as the physical world? Whether you studied at the College of Dimensional Studies in Katapesh or an underground school in haunted Ustalav, you've turned your magic past the Universe to the forces beyond, summoning spirits and shades, manipulating dimensions and planes, and treading in a place not meant for mortals.

You eschew the idea that magic can be neatly expressed by the teachings of any single school or college, instead directing your self-study to pick up the best of every school of magic. In doing so, you'll find the truths that lie at the intersection of each school, coming closer to the ideal nature of arcane magic. One day, you'll uncover that single elegant theory detailing all magic (perhaps a theory bearing your name?), but until then, your studies continue.
You don't have a set curriculum, and so you don't have curriculum spells and can't benefit from abilities that specifically affect them. Instead, you gain an additional 1st-level wizard class feat, and you add one 1st- rank spell of your choice to your spellbook to represent your diverse studies.

Protective Wards (1 Action)
Focus Spell
Area 5-foot emanation centered on you
Duration sustained up to 1 minute
You expand a ring of glyphs that shields your allies. You and any allies in the area gain a +1 status bonus to AC. Each time you Sustain the spell, the emanation's radius increases by 5 feet, to a maximum of 30 feet.

Force Bolt (1 Action)
Focus Spell
Range 30 feet
Targets 1 creature
You fire an arrow-shaped bolt of force, one of the most common and reliable forms of battle magic. It automatically hits and deals 1d4+1 force damage to the target.
Heightened (+2) The damage increases by 1d4+1.

Earthworks (1 action to 3 actions)
Focus Spell
Range 60 feet; Area 5-foot burst or more
Duration 1 minute
With a ripple of earth, you raise small barriers from the ground. The ground in the area becomes difficult terrain. The spell's area is a 5-foot burst if you spent 1 action to cast it, a 10-foot burst if you spent 2 actions, or a 15-foot burst if you spent 3 actions. A creature can Interact to clear the barriers from one 5-foot square adjacent to it.

Charming Push (1 action)
Focus Spell
Range 30 feet; Targets 1 creature
Defense Will; Duration until the start of your next turn
You push at the target's mind to deflect their ire. The target must attempt a Will save.
Success The target takes a â€“1 circumstance penalty to attack rolls and damage rolls against you.
Failure The target can't use hostile actions against you.

Scramble Body (2 actions)
Range 30 feet; Targets 1 creature
Defense Fortitude
Your magic throws the creature's biology into disarray, inducing nausea, fever, and other unpleasant conditions.
Failure The target becomes sickened 1.

Fortify Summoning (1 action)
Range 30 feet; Targets 1 creature you summoned
As you call a creature to your side, your magic transforms its body, heightening its ferocity and fortifying its resilience. The target gains a +1 status bonus to all checks and DCs (including its AC) for the duration of its summoning, up to 1 minute.

Hand of the Apprentice (1 action)
Range 500 feet; Targets 1 creature
Defense AC
You take advantage of one of the most fundamental lessons of magic to levitate and propel your weapon. You hurl a held melee weapon with which you are trained at the target, making a spell attack roll. On a success, you deal the weapon's damage as if you had hit with a melee Strike, but add your spellcasting attribute modifier to damage, rather than your Strength modifier. On a critical success, you deal double damage, and you add the weapon's critical specialization effect. Regardless of the outcome, the weapon flies back to you and returns to your hand.
You fire an arrow-shaped bolt of force, one of the most common and reliable forms of battle magic. It automatically hits and deals 1d4+1 force damage to the target.

You have a strong connection to beasts, always feeling like you understood them (and they you) better than your own people. You stand for the animals of nature, a powerful animal companion at your side.
Anathema Commit wanton cruelty to animals or kill animals unnecessarily. (This doesnâ€™t prevent you from defending yourself against animals or killing them cleanly for food).
You call a minor spirit of nature into a plant body, creating a leshy companion to aid you in your spellcasting.

You're as enduring as stone, and you take comfort in its steadfast presence, both natural and worked.
Poisoning or polluting the land and heedlessly carving the earth to plunder its natural resources are anathema to your order (this doesn't prevent you from responsibly digging or mining).
You are at home out in the elements, reveling in the power of nature unleashed. Ignore concealment from fog.

The uncontrollable call of the natural world courses through your body. You might have been raised by a wild animal, or you might have come to reject the artifices of cities after growing up in one. Now, primal magic grants you the ability to wear the form of an untamed creature.
Anathema Become fully domesticated by the temptations of civilization. (This doesnâ€™t prevent you from buying and using processed goods or staying in a city for an adventure, but you can never come to rely on these conveniences or truly call such a place your permanent home.)
You ignore difficult terrain resulting from water and ice.

2 Actions
A thin layer of ash and flame covers the ground in the area. The area becomes hazardous terrain. A creature that moves on the ground through the area takes 1 fire damage for every square of that area it moves into
Plump and juicy, this berry exudes a soothing, sweet smell.

Vines twine into a wicker horn in your hands, and out spills a single fruit, nut, or similar small bit of produce. A creature who eats the produce with an Interact action regains 1d6+4 HP. The cornucopia, as well as any unconsumed pieces of fruit, wither away at the end of the duration.
Heightened (+1) The cornucopia produces an additional piece of food.

You tear open the ground then slam it shut. The target creature takes 2d6 bludgeoning damage with a Reflex save.
Success The target takes half damage.
Failure The target takes full damage and is flat-footed
Critical Failure The target takes double damage and is flat-footed and immobilized.
Heightened (+1) Increase the initial damage by 2d6.

You surround a foe in a swirling storm of violent winds, roiling clouds, and crackling lightning. The storm deals 1d12 electricity damage to the target with a basic Reflex save. On a failure, the target also is clumsy 2 for 1 round.

You create a wave of water that you ride, banking around obstacles and surfing to higher ground. You move up to 35 feet, raising yourself up to 5 feet above the ground. (You can avoid many types of difficult terrain in this way.) You must end your movement on an unoccupied space where you have solid footing. This movement isn't a Stride, but you measure the distance in a similar way, and it still triggers reactions caused by movement. You can't transport anyone else with you.
Heightened (+2) Increase the distance you move by 5 feet and the maximum height traveled above the ground by 5 feet.
Your affinity for the natural world grants you protection against some of its dangers. You gain poison resistance equal to half your level
Your connection to heat and flame means that fire is reluctant to bring its full force to bear against you. You gain fire resistance equal to half your level
You can always find a path, almost as if foliage parted before you. You ignore any difficult terrain
You can focus on two foes at once, hunting both of them down. When you use the Hunt Prey action, you can pick two creatures as your prey.
You point out vulnerabilities present in your hunted prey, allowing an ally to share your hunter's edge.
Gains the benefits of the source's hunter's edge against their hunted prey.
You point out vulnerabilities present in your hunted prey, allowing an ally to use your hunter's edge.
When you Hunt Prey, your animal companion gains the action's benefits and your hunter's edge benefit if you have one.
Gains the benefits of the source's hunter's edge against their hunted prey.

The number of times you can channel your divine powers.
A spell caused by your patronâ€™s direct attention and intervention. You can cast only one spell that has the hex trait each turn.

You use your two weapons to parry attacks. You gain a +1 circumstance bonus to AC until the start of your next turn, or a +2 circumstance bonus if either weapon has the parry trait.

You infuse yourself with primal essence and transform yourself into another form. You can add more forms to your wild shape list with druid feats; your feat might grant you some or all of the forms from a given polymorph spell.
The target is off-guard against the next melee attack that you attempt against it before the end of your current turn.
The target is off-guard against melee attacks that you attempt against it until the end of your next turn.

When a creature critically misses you while you are using Twin Parry, you may Strike them.
When a creature critically misses you while you are using Twin Parry, you may Disarm them.

You can urge your companion to do its utmost. You can spend 2 actions to Command an Animal instead of 1 when commanding your animal companion. If you do, your animal companion uses an additional action.

When the Strike is complete, you resume gripping the weapon with only one hand. This action doesnâ€™t end any stance or fighter feat effect that requires you to have one hand free.

You might also be at war with an uncontrollable, animalistic side of your personality, or you might be a descendant of a werewolf or another werecreature.

Your rage gives you the raw power and size of a giant. This doesnâ€™t necessarily mean you revere giantsâ€”you might scoff at them or even aspire to slay them!

You eschew the idea that magic can be neatly expressed by the teachings of any single school or college, instead directing your self-study to pick up the best of every school of magic. In doing so, you'll find the truths that lie at the intersection of each school, coming closer to the ideal nature of arcane magic. One day, you'll uncover that single elegant theory detailing all magic (perhaps a theory bearing your name?), but until then, your studies continue.
You don't have a set curriculum, and so you don't have curriculum spells and can't benefit from abilities that specifically affect them. Instead, you gain an additional 1st-level wizard class feat, and you add one 1st- rank spell of your choice to your spellbook to represent your diverse studies.

Why use your magic to affect something as pedestrian as the physical world? Whether you studied at the College of Dimensional Studies in Katapesh or an underground school in haunted Ustalav, you've turned your magic past the Universe to the forces beyond, summoning spirits and shades, manipulating dimensions and planes, and treading in a place not meant for mortals.

The uninitiated often think of wizards as cerebral, focused on their studies more than the body, yet your school of magic taught of the relationship between the two. Your magic, whether learned at a storied institution like Kintargo's Alabaster Academy or someplace more sinister, like the Fleshforges of Nex, focuses on the ways that living matter can be convinced into another shape for a time, allowing you to polymorph a seed into a vine, a human into a beast, or a harmless germ into a deadly toxin.

As a scholar, you know all too well the importance of a sound mind. Thus, you attended a schoolâ€”like the Farseer Tower or the Stone of the Seersâ€”that taught the arts of befuddling lesser minds with figments and illusions or implanted sensations and memories.

Whether you studied in Manaket's Occularium or the Academy of Applied Magic, you learned that the fruits of arcane studiesâ€”like any other fieldâ€”should ultimately help the common citizen. You've learned the humble art of construction, of finding lost people and things, of moving speedily among buildings and moatsâ€”yet these same arts can be turned to demolition, and the constructs you animate to build bridges can just as easily tear them down.

Magic is power, and there are always those who will use power for the art of battle. You may have studied in the military of a nation of the brink of warâ€”Cheliax and Andoran perhaps, or Geb and Nex. You summon whirling energies that can lay waste to both soldiers and armies, while being sure not to neglect arcane countermeasures for common tactical complications or the shields and defenses that keep combatants alive on the battlefield.
You can prepare your tactics to suit different situations. You gain one fighter feat of 8th level or lower. You can change this feat later.

Runes and wards, numbers and lettersâ€”they underpin all magic, making them the logical subject for a wizard who studies fundamental forces. Perhaps you studied at the Pathfinder Society's School of Spells or a similar institution, but whether you're lacing your words with magic to compel others, casting wards around your workshop, or destabilizing the very structure of an opponent's spells, you know this unassuming school carries elegant power.

A single feeling radiated from your patron in the moment you met them, as palpable as heat from a fire: the desire to see every tall poppy felled and every proud nail hammered down, whether to righteously bring justice for small folk or the base urge to see the powerful defeated. Your patron is likely far from the upper echelons of its kind, such as a hag ousted from its coven or a quasi-divinity or a lower-rank demon. This leaves it only subtler and weaker tools to see its ends met: curses, hexes, and you.

1 Action
Rage
Through the haze of battle, you quickly recover your raging vigor. You gain temporary Hit Points equal to half your level plus your Constitution modifier. If you made an attack action this turn, increase the number of temporary Hit Points to your level plus your Constitution modifier. These temporary Hit Points last until the end of your rage.

2 or 3 Actions
Rage
You rush forward. Stride up to five times, or up to eight times if you used 3 actions. All this movement must be in a straight line (though the GM might allow reasonable variance).

1 Action
Rage
Requirements Your last action was a successful Strike.
The weight of your swing drives your enemy back. You push the enemy back 5 feet, with the effects of a successful Shove. You can follow the enemy as normal for a successful Shove.

Reaction
Rage
Your vicious strike pulls your foe closer, giving you the opportunity to grab them. Attempt to Grapple the triggering enemy.

You sprout dragon wings from your back of the same color as your chosen dragon. While you are raging, you gain a fly Speed equal to your land Speed. If you are flying when your rage ends, you start to fall, but your transformation doesn't revert until the last moment, so you take no damage from the fall and land standing up. This action gains the trait of your dragon instinct's tradition.

Reaction
Rage
Ignoring your pain, you reach out and grab the creature or weapon that caused you harm. Attempt an Athletics check to Grapple the triggering creature or to Disarm the creature of the weapon it damaged you with.

1 Action
Rage
Requirements Your last action was a successful Strike, and either you have a hand free or your Strike used a weapon with the grapple trait.
You grab your foe while it's distracted by your attack. The enemy you hit becomes grabbed by you, as if you had succeeded at an Athletics check to Grapple it.

1 Action
Flourish, Rage
You close the distance to your prey in a blur, pouncing on the creature before it can react. You Stride up to your Speed and make a Strike at the end of your movement.

1 Action
Attack,Rage
You call forth an ephemeral spirit, typically the apparition of an ancestor or a nature spirit, which takes the form of a wisp. The wisp makes a melee wisp rush unarmed attack against an enemy within 120 feet of you. The wisp's attack modifier is equal to your proficiency bonus for martial weapons plus your Strength modifier plus a +2 item bonus, and it applies the same circumstance and status bonuses and penalties that you have. On a hit, the wisp deals spirit damage equal to 4d8 plus your Constitution modifier. Don't apply your Rage damage or your weapon specialization damage, but circumstance and status bonuses and penalties that would also affect the wisp's damage apply. On a critical hit, the wisp deals double damage and the target becomes frightened 1. This attack uses and counts toward your multiple attack penalty as if you were the one attacking.
You grow to even greater size. When using Giant's Stature, you can instead become Huge (increasing your reach by 10 feet if you were Medium or smaller).

3 Actions
You make a great sweep with your weapon or fists about yourself, knocking creatures off their feet and away from you. Choose up to three enemies within your reach and choose whether to Shove or Trip all three of them. Whichever of the two options you choose, roll a separate Athletics check against each enemy, performing the same action against each enemy. Each attempt counts toward your multiple attack penalty, but don't increase your penalty until you have made all the attempts.

Attack,Rage
You call forth an ephemeral spirit, typically the apparition of an ancestor or a nature spirit, which takes the form of a wisp. The wisp makes a melee wisp rush unarmed attack against an enemy within 120 feet of you. The wisp's attack modifier is equal to your proficiency bonus for martial weapons plus your Strength modifier plus a +2 item bonus, and it applies the same circumstance and status bonuses and penalties that you have. On a hit, the wisp deals spirit damage equal to 4d8 plus your Constitution modifier. Don't apply your Rage damage or your weapon specialization damage, but circumstance and status bonuses and penalties that would also affect the wisp's damage apply. On a critical hit, the wisp deals double damage and the target becomes frightened 1. This attack uses and counts toward your multiple attack penalty as if you were the one attacking.

3 Actions

Each attempt counts toward your multiple attack penalty, but don't increase your penalty until you have made all the attempts.

Rage
You rush forward. Stride up to five times

Rage
You rush forward. Stride up to eight times

1 Action
Rage
Requirements Your last action was a successful Strike, and either you have a hand free or your Strike used a weapon with the grapple trait.
You grab your foe while it's distracted by your attack. The enemy you hit becomes grabbed by you, as if you had succeeded at an Athletics check to Grapple it.

Your rage intensifies and lets you hit harder at the start of a fight. Your proficiency rank for your barbarian class DC increases to expert. In addition, when you use Quick-Tempered, the first Strike you make during your first turn deals additional damage equal to your Rage damage.
Repeated exposure and toughened skin allow you to fend off harm. While raging, you gain resistance equal to 3 + your Constitution modifier to damage types based on your instinct.

Your muse constantly inspires you to greater heights of artistic prowess. For many bards, a teacher or rival fills this role, although some set their sights higher and attempt to surpass great composers of the past or blaze a new trail entirely. If your muse is a supernatural creature, it might be one who loves to perform, such as a choral angel or a lyrakien azata; if a deity, it might be Shelyn. Art inspired by a maestro muse is precise and inventive, a formalist achievement.

Your muse is a jack of all trades, flitting between skills and pursuits. Some bards are constantly moved by new muses or draw their inspiration from an idealized being, whether it's based on a real person or purely philosophical. If your muse is a single creature, it might be an eclectic creature like a fey or one who's learned a lot over a long lifespan; if a deity, it might be Desna or Calistria. Art inspired by a polymath muse is restless, with each composition exhibiting new techniques and an ever-evolving style.

The battlefield is your stage, the clang of steel, your song. Your muse has seen countless battles, whether reveling in combat or resigned to its necessity. An individual soldier or general might inspire you, but so might a battlefield or weapon with a particularly profound history. If your muse is a creature, it might be an otherworldly soldier, such as an archon or devil soldier. If it's a deity, it might be Gorum. Art inspired by a warrior muse is triumphant and strident, often detailing epic battles.

Your muse is a master of birdsong, wolf howls, trumpeting elephants, and other animal communication, pushing you to new heights and encouraging your connections with nature. If your muse is a creature, it might be an enlightened animal or a spirit guide. If it's a deity, it might be one of the Wardens of the Wild, Gozreh, or another representative of nature.

Infused with void energy. Takes a -1 status penalty to AC for 1 round.
Infused with powerful vitality. Gains a +1 status bonus to AC for 1 round.
Impelled by devilish orders. +1 status bonus to attack rolls and skill checks.

You feel ill. Sickened always includes a value. You take a status penalty equal to this value on all your checks and DCs. You can't willingly ingest anythingâ€”including elixirs and potionsâ€”while sickened.
An enemy within [1] takes a â€“1 status penalty to the next saving throw they attempt against a spell you cast before the end of your turn.

When you successfully Feint, the target is off-guard against your melee attacks until the end of your next turn. On a critical success, the target is off-guard against all melee attacks until the end of your next turn, not just yours.
If you Feint while wielding an agile or finesse melee weapon, you can Step immediately after the Feint as a free action.

You use fast-talking, flattery, and a silver tongue to avoid danger and escape tricky situations. You might be a grifter or con artist, or you might use your skills in certain reputable professions, like a barrister or diplomat.
You're tired and can't summon much energy. You take a â€“1 status penalty to AC and saving throws.
Once this Rage ends, you become fatigued for the rest of combat.

Desperate to finish the fight, you pour all your rage into one final blow. Make a Strike. If it hits, you gain a circumstance bonus to damage equal to the number of rounds remaining in your Rage (maximum 10). After this Strike, your Rage immediately ends, and you are fatigued until you rest for at least 10 minutes.
Actions with the flourish trait are special techniques that require too much exertion for you to perform frequently. You can use only one action with the flourish trait per round.
The creature can't use reactions and takes a â€“2 status penalty to Perception checks and Will saves.
The creature can't use reactions and takes a â€“2 status penalty to Perception checks and Will saves.
You step carefully and quickly. You can <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_Disengage">Step</LSTag> though <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="DIFFICULT_TERRAIN">difficult terrain</LSTag>.
Hitting an <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="OFF_BALANCED">off-guard</LSTag> creature with a light, finesse, or ranged attack deals an extra [1] precision damage.
<LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="SURPRISED">Suprised</LSTag> creatures that haven't acted are <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="OFF_BALANCED">off-guard</LSTag> to you.
Deal extra precision damage to an <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="OFF_BALANCED">off-guard</LSTag> foe.
Also works if you have an ally within [1] of the target.
You have progressed along your own path to enlightenment. Choose your Fortitude, Reflex, or Will saving throw. Your proficiency rank for the chosen saving throw increases to master.
The strong embrace the wild that hides inside - keen instincts, primal physicality, and most of all, an unbridled, unquenchable rage.

You have trained to aim for your preyâ€™s weak points. The first time you hit your hunted prey in a round, you also deal 1d8 additional precision damage. (Precision damage increases the damage you already deal, using the same type, but is ineffective against creatures that lack vital organs or weak points.) At 11th level, the extra damage increases to 2d8 precision damage, and at 19th level, the extra damage increases to 3d8 precision damage.

You are talented at outwitting and evading your prey. You gain a +2 circumstance bonus to Deception checks, Intimidation checks, Stealth checks, and any checks to Recall Knowledge about the prey, and a +1 circumstance bonus to AC against your prey's attacks.

You have trained to unleash a devastating flurry of attacks upon your prey. Your multiple attack penalty for attacks against your hunted prey is â€“3 (â€“2 with an agile weapon) on your second attack of the turn instead of â€“5, and â€“6 (â€“4 with an agile weapon) on your third or subsequent attack of the turn, instead of â€“10.

Your studies make you informed on every subject. You have <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">advantage</LSTag> on all <LSTag Tooltip="Intelligence">Intelligence</LSTag> <LSTag Tooltip="SkillCheck">skill checks</LSTag> made outside of combat.
Your muse is a mystery, driving you to uncover the hidden secrets of life and the multiverse. You support your allies by providing knowledge alongside inspiration and occult support.
You're as enduring as stone, and you take comfort in its steadfast presence, both natural and worked.

You have a strong connection to beasts, always feeling like you understood them (and they you) better than your own people. You stand for the animals of nature, a powerful animal companion at your side.

Whether you were born under a tempest or survived a bolt of lightning from a clear blue sky, you now carry the fury of the storm in your heart, channeling thunder to terrifying destructive effect and riding the winds through the air.
You feel a kinship with flames and can use them for succor and destruction.
You call a minor spirit of nature into a plant body, creating a leshy companion to aid you in your spellcasting.
Water is the source of life, and you've learned to shape how it flows.
Choose the element that influenced your bloodline: air, earth, fire, metal, water, or wood. You can't change this later. You are granted different spells at certain ranks according to this influence.

You can rely on the grandeur of your performances rather than ordinary social skills. You can use <LSTag Tooltip="Performance">Performance</LSTag> instead of <LSTag Tooltip="Intimidation">Intimidation</LSTag> to <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_Demoralize">Demoralize</LSTag>, and use your acting skills to <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_InfiltrationExpertise">disguise</LSTag> yourself.
You add a flourish to your composition to extend its benefits. Attempt a DC [1] Performance check. If you succeed, increase its duration by 2 rounds.
You add a flourish to your composition to extend its benefits. Attempt a DC [1] Performance check. If you succeed, increase its duration by 2 rounds.

When you have <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_CourageousAnthem">Courageous Anthem</LSTag> active, and you damage an enemy with a Strike, the spellâ€™s duration is extended by 1 round. You can extend an individual casting only once in this way.

As a favored agent of your patron, you can invoke their power for a more direct magical intervention. A hex is a spell shaped by your patron and sent to you through your familiar, rather than an ability you use directly.
At your unspoken plea, your patron temporarily assumes control over your familiar. You Command your familiar, allowing it to take its normal actions this turn.
At your unspoken plea, your patron temporarily assumes control over your familiar. You Command your familiar, allowing it to take its normal actions this turn.
Eyes blanketed in darkness. Other creatures are concealed to it.
If your familiar is adjacent to an enemy to which it's concealed, hidden, or undetected, the enemy becomes frightened 1.
If your familiar is adjacent to an enemy to which it's concealed, hidden, or undetected, the enemy becomes frightened 1.
Against the triggering damage, your familiar gains resistance [1] to all damage.
Against the triggering damage, your familiar gains resistance [1] to all damage.

Range 30 feet
Targets you or 1 ally
Duration sustained up to 4 rounds
Your glorious singing mends wounds and provides a temporary respite from harm. The target gains fast healing 2. When you Cast the Spell and the first time each round you Sustain the Spell, the target gains 2 temporary Hit Points, which last for 1 round.
Heightened (+1) The fast healing and temporary Hit Points each increase by 2

Auditory
Prerequisites zoophonia muse
You can convey the subtle menace of a low growl or predatory rumble. Attempt a Performance check, and compare it to the Will DC of each enemy adjacent to you. For each creature that you succeed at, it's frightened 1. Regardless of the result, each target is temporarily immune to your Bestial Snarling for 10 minutes.

Prerequisites warrior muse
Area 60-foot emanation
Duration 1 round
You bolster your allies' physical strength with a hearty exhortation. You and your allies gain a +1 status bonus to Athletics checks.

Area 60-foot Emanation
Duration 1 Round
Your song moves allies to protect themselves more effectively. You and all allies in the area gain a +1 status bonus to AC and saving throws, as well as resistance equal to half the spell's rank to physical damage.

Area 60-foot Emanation
Duration 1 Round
Your music sets a fast pace. You and all allies in the area gain a +10-foot status bonus to all Speeds for 1 round.

Area 30-foot emanation
Duration 1 round
Enemies within the area are frightened 1. They can't reduce their frightened value below 1 while they remain in the area.

Prerequisites maestro muse
1 Action
You can perform multiple compositions simultaneously, typically by performing in multiple ways at the same time, using special vocal techniques to double your voice, or creating occult magic that replicates your song or speech. If your next action is to cast a composition, it becomes a harmonized composition. Unlike a normal composition, a harmonized composition doesnâ€™t end if you cast another composition, and you can cast another composition on the same turn as a harmonized one. Casting another harmonized composition ends any harmonized composition you already have in effect.

Make a <LSTag Tooltip="Performance">Performance</LSTag> check against each foe adjacent to either you or your beast minion. On a success, they are <LSTag Tooltip="FRIGHTENED">frightened 1</LSTag>, and beasts are <LSTag Tooltip="FRIGHTENED">frightened 2</LSTag>.

You can cast only one composition spell each turn, and you can have only one active at a time. If you cast a new composition spell, any ongoing effects from your previous composition spell end immediately.

Prerequisites maestro muse
Free Action
Spellshape
You call upon your muse to greatly increase the benefits you provide with your courageous anthem, rallying anthem, or song of strength composition. If your next action is to cast one of these compositions, attempt a Performance check. The DC is usually the highest Will DC of the composition's targets, but the GM can assign a different DC based on the circumstances. The effect of your composition depends on the result of your check.

When you cast <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Shout_CourageousAnthem">Courageous Anthem</LSTag>, one ally of your choice who gains a status bonus from the spell can immediately use their reaction to make a <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="CourageousAssault_Strike">melee Strike<LSTag>.

You mime an invisible 10-foot-by-10-foot wall adjacent to you and within your reach. The wall is solid to those creatures that don't disbelieve it, even incorporeal creatures. You and your allies can voluntarily believe the wall exists to continue to treat it as solid, for instance to climb onto it. A creature that disbelieves the illusion is temporarily immune to your house of imaginary walls for 1 minute. The wall doesn't block creatures that didn't see your visual performance, nor does it block objects. The wall has AC 10, Hardness equal to double the spell's rank, and HP equal to quadruple the spell's rank.

Your voice calls a storm of songbirds that whirl around you and peck at your enemies. All creatures within the area of whirling birds become concealed, and all creatures outside the area become concealed to creatures within it. A creature other than you that enters or ends its turn in the area takes 1d6 piercing damage as the birds peck at it.

You mime an invisible 10-foot-by-10-foot wall adjacent to you and within your reach. The wall is solid to those creatures that don't disbelieve it, even incorporeal creatures. You and your allies can voluntarily believe the wall exists to continue to treat it as solid, for instance to climb onto it. A creature that disbelieves the illusion is temporarily immune to your house of imaginary walls for 1 minute. The wall doesn't block creatures that didn't see your visual performance, nor does it block objects. The wall has AC 10, Hardness equal to double the spell's rank, and HP equal to quadruple the spell's rank.

1 Action
Focus, Stance
You adopt the stance of clinging shadows. You can make shadow grasp Strikes. These deal 1d4 void damage; are in the brawling group; and have the agile, grapple, reach, and unarmed traits. While in clinging shadows stance, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to Athletics checks to Grapple, and to the DC for creatures to Escape from you.

1 Action
Stance
Requirements You are unarmored
You enter the stance of impenetrable iron, refusing to yield to any blow. You can make iron sweep unarmed attacks. These deal 1d8 bludgeoning damage; are in the brawling group; and have the nonlethal, parry, sweep, and unarmed traits.
While in Ironblood Stance, you gain resistance 2 to all damage. The resistance increases to 3 at 12th level, to 4 at 16th level, and to 5 at 20th level.

2 Actions
You leverage your knowledge of martial arts to mix different maneuvers together into a single flowing combination. Choose any two of Grapple, Reposition, Shove, and Trip. Attempt both of the attacks you chose against the same or different creatures, but don't apply the multiple attack penalty until after resolving both attacks.

Reaction
Trigger You use Flurry of Blows to make two ranged piercing weapon Strikes against the same target.
You target your opponent's clothing, equipment, or loose flesh with a series of piercing projectiles to pin them to the ground or a nearby surface. If both your attacks hit, the target must succeed at a Reflex save against your class DC or become immobilized until it or an adjacent creature succeeds at a DC 10 Athletics check to remove the pinning projectiles.

Prerequisites Deflect Projectile
You pluck missiles from the air and hurl them back at their source. When you successfully deflect an attack with Deflect Projectile, as part of that same reaction, you can then immediately make a ranged Strike against the attacker using the projectile you deflected. This is a thrown weapon with the same range increment and effect on a hit as the triggering attack.

Requirements You are unarmored
You extend your arms like gnarled branches to interfere with your foes' movements. You can make lashing branch unarmed attacks. These deal 1d8 slashing damage; are in the brawling group; and have the agile, finesse, nonlethal, and unarmed traits.
While you're in Tangled Forest Stance and can act, every enemy in your reach that tries to move away from you must succeed at a Reflex save, Acrobatics check, or Athletics check against your class DC or be immobilized for that action.

1 Action
You defy gravity, traversing vertical planes as easily as the ground. Stride up to your Speed. You must start your movement on a horizontal surface. During this movement, you can run up vertical surfaces, like walls, at your full Speed. If you end the Stride off the ground, you fall after taking your next action or when your turn ends, whichever comes first (though you can Grab an Edge, if applicable). If you have Water Step or a similar ability, Wall Run lets you run along flimsy vertical surfaces, as well as vertical liquids, such as a waterfall.

Focus, Stance
You take on the stance of the flowing winds, sending out waves of energy at a distance. You can make wind crash unarmed Strikes as ranged Strikes against targets within 30 feet. These deal 1d6 bludgeoning damage; are in the brawling group; and have the agile, nonlethal, propulsive, and unarmed traits. Wind crash Strikes ignore concealment and all cover.

1 Action
Frequency once per minute
Prerequisites Cobra Stance
Requirements You are in Cobra Stance
You slightly dislocate your joints to lash out with devious intent and the power to envenom your foe. Make a cobra fang Strike. Your reach with this Strike is 5 feet greater than normal. When you are targetted, you attempt a DC 17 flat check. On a success, you aren't targetted.
Creator Note: Concealed is a DC 5 which is 20% chance to miss and DC 17 is also a 20% chance, though I know it doesn't look like it from the two numbers. We can't code attackers to make such a roll, so this is the closest mechanical effect we could emulate. In this case, attacks that would miss from this have a massive penalty to hit and saving throws you attempt have a massive bonus.

2 Actions
Range 60 feet
Area 10-foot burst
Duration 1 minute
You create an echo of a powerful poltergeist, temporarily anchoring it to the area to terrorize and harm any opponents foolish enough to remain in the area. Because the poltergeist is a manifestation and is not truly present, it can't be attacked or hurt; it remains invisible unless otherwise stated. When you Cast the Spell, and the first time you Sustain it on subsequent rounds, the poltergeist creates your choice of one of the following effects.
Deathly Assault (negative) The poltergeist focuses on one creature in the area and flies through that creature's space, dealing 4d10 negative damage (basic Fortitude save).
Frighten (emotion, fear, mental) The poltergeist becomes visible, appearing as a skeletal, ghostlike humanoid. Creatures in the area must attempt a Will save, becoming frightened 2 on a failure.
Telekinetic Storm (force) The poltergeist hurls debris and quasi-real objects around in the area. All creatures in the area take 4d8 force damage (basic Reflex save).
Heightened (+2) The damage of the deathly assault effect increases by 1d10, and the damage of the telekinetic storm effect increases by 1d8.

Creator Note: Concealed is a DC 5 which is 20% chance to miss and DC 17 is also a 20% chance, though I know it doesn't look like it from the two numbers. We can't code attackers to make such a roll, so this is the closest mechanical effect we could emulate. In this case, attacks that would miss from this have a massive penalty to hit and saving throws you attempt have a massive bonus.

You live under the desert's blazing heat, gaining incredible resilience to warm environments. You gain fire resistance equal to half your level (minimum 1).

Reaction
Call On Ancient Blood
Trigger You attempt a saving throw against a magical effect

You eagerly absorbed the old stories and traditions of your ancestors, your gods, and your people, studying subjects and techniques passed down for generation upon generation. The blood of the fey flows through your veins, saturating you with their magic and making you truly one of them. You gain the fey trait, in addition to the gnome and humanoid traits. Some other source of magic has a greater hold on you than the primal magic of your fey lineage does. This connection might come from an occult plane or an ancient occult song; a deity, celestial, or fiend; magical effluent left behind by a mage war; or ancient rune magic.
Whether from a connection to dark or shadowy fey, from the underground gnomes known as drathnelar, or from another source, you can see in complete darkness. You gain darkvision.
Small yet capable, halflings prefer the comforts of home and hearth - but their natural luck and dexterity makes them fine adventurers.

You hail from deep within a jungle or forest, and you've learned how to use your small size to wriggle through undergrowth and other obstacles. You ignore any difficult terrain caused by plants and fungi, such as bushes, vines, and undergrowth.

Your ancestors performed many secret acts under the concealing cover of dusk, whether for good or ill, and over time they developed the ability to see in twilight beyond even the usual keen sight of halflings. You gain darkvision.

Each creature in the area must attempt a basic saving throw against the higher of your class DC or spell DC. You can't use this ability again for 1d4 rounds.
At 3rd level and every 2 levels thereafter, the damage increases by 1d4. The shape of the breath, the damage type, and the saving throw match those of your draconic exemplar (see above). This ability has the trait associated with the type of damage it deals.
While not wearing armor you have a +1 bonus to AC. This increases to +2 at 5th level.

You were raised by a tiefling or a fiendish relative, or you've devoted yourself to researching the secrets of the fiendish realms. You gain the trained proficiency rank in Intimidation and Religion. If you would automatically become trained in one of those skills (from your background or class, for example), you instead become trained in a skill of your choice.

Traditionally, fiends are exceptionally good at persuading people to do things, even when their targets know it's a bad idea. You're also rather good at it, compelling the weak and weak-willed to your bidding. You can cast charm once per day as a 1st-level divine innate spell.
Your skin glows with bioluminescent color, casting bright light in a 20-foot emanation (and dim light for the next 20 feet). This light can be any color.

Your skin is medium armor in the plate armor group that grants a +4 item bonus to AC, and has a Dex cap of +1. You can never wear other armor or remove your hide. You can etch armor runes onto your hide.
Spew forth a cone of acid.
Spew forth a cone of ice.
Spew forth a cone of fire.
Spew forth a column of fire.
Spew forth a line of lightning.
Spew forth a cone of poison.
It costs half as much gold for you to scribe spells.

If you Cast this Spell with 2 actions, it has an area of a 60-foot cone; if you Cast this Spell with 3 actions, it has a range of 500 feet and an area of a 30-foot burst. Each creature in the area takes 10d6 cold damage with a basic Reflex save. Snowdrifts and icy gales fill the area until the start of your next turn, making the area difficult terrain.
Heightened (+1) The damage increases by 2d6.

2 Actions
You conjure a spike that thrusts up from the earth beneath a target creature, potentially impaling it. The spike is made of cold iron and deals 8d6 piercing damage. The target must attempt a Reflex save.
Success The target is struck by the spike and takes half damage.
Failure The target is impaled through a leg or another non-vital body part. The creature takes full damage and, if it's standing on solid ground, becomes immobilized.
Heightened (+1) The damage increases by 2d6.

2 Actions
Ragged apparitions of the dead rise to stalk the living. They deal 2d4 mental damage and 2d4 void damage to each living creature in the area, with a basic Will save.
On subsequent rounds, the first time you Sustain the spell each round, you can move the area up to 30 feet within the range of the spell. Living creatures in the new area must attempt saves with the same effects as above

2 Actions
You speed up the time stream in an area, stretching and pulling it until time flows swift and wild. Any creature that begins its turn in the area is quickened and can use the extra action each round to Stride or Strike. Unfortunately, speeding up time is much more difficult than slowing it down, and the effect is uneven and jittery, making accuracy between times painfully difficult; creatures inside the area are concealed to those outside it, and vice versa.

2 Action
You supernaturally rip the spirit from a living creature's body, dooming the target to pain and death. 1 to 3 Actions
Range 120 feet
Area 5-foot burst or more
Duration 1 minute
Ground in the area turns swampy and fetid. The area is difficult terrain. The sludge at the bottom of the morass animates into diminutive sludge beasts that have a demonic appearance. These don't function as normal creatures, but they swarm over creatures in the swamp and exude a noxious stench. The swamp deals 1d6 poison damage to creatures that end their turn in the area (basic Fortitude save). For each additional action you use when Casting the Spell, increase the burst's radius by 5 feet.

1 Action
You close your hand and pull life energy from another creature into yourself. This deals 3d4 void damage; the target must attempt a basic Fortitude save. You gain 3d4 temporary Hit Points. The temporary Hit Points last for 1 minute.
Heightened (+1) The damage and temporary hit points increases by 1d4.
A creature that ends its turn in the swamp takes 1d6 poison damage
A creature that ends its turn in the swamp takes 1d6 poison damage
A creature that begins its turn in the area takes 8d6 acid damage (basic Reflex save).
A creature that begins its turn in the area takes 8d6 acid damage (basic Reflex save).
You take [1] less damage from physical damage.
You take [1] less damage from physical damage.

Devil horns grow from your skull, and your skin takes on features of the devil responsible for your diabolic bloodline. You gain resistance 5 to fire and poison, and resistance 1 to physical damage
Heightened (+2) The resistance to fire and poison increase by 5, and the resistance to physical damage by 2.

1 Action
You become invisible and ignore natural difficult terrain (such as underbrush). Any hostile action you use ends this invisibility, but you still ignore natural difficult terrain.
Heightened (5th) If you use a hostile action, the invisibility doesn't end.

2 Actions
You briefly transform your features into the horrific visage of a hag, striking fear into your enemies. Foes in the area must attempt a Will save.
Failure The foe is frightened 1.
Heightened (5th) Foes in the area are frightened 1 on a success, frightened 2 on a failure, and frightened 3 and fleeing for 1 round on a critical failure. They are still unaffected on a critical success.

2 Actions
Area 30-foot cone
You spew energy from your mouth, dealing 5d6 damage with a basic Reflex save. The damage type depends on the magical tradition related to the dragon that influenced your bloodline: arcane force, divine spirit, occult mental, or primal fire.
Heightened (+1) The damage increases by 2d6.

2 Actions
Area 30-foot cone
You spew energy from your mouth, dealing 5d6 damage with a basic Reflex save. The damage type depends on the magical tradition related to the dragon that influenced your bloodline: arcane force, divine spirit, occult mental, or primal fire.
Heightened (+1) The damage increases by 2d6.
